explanations: In all verbs of this group, the last sound of the ます-form is from the い-column of the syllabary group
In most verbs of this group, the last sound of the ます-form is from the え-column of the syllabary group
In some verbs of this group, it is a sound from the い-column
Verbs of the group include します and きます
Other verbs of this group have ます-form that ends in します
Mosts verbs of this group are actually action-denoting nouns with します appended to them to transform them into a verb
When last sound of the ます-form is い, ち or り, it is dropped and って is added
When last sound of the ます-form is み, び or に, it is dropped and んで is added
When last sound of the ます-form is き or ぎ, it is dropped and いて or いで is added
When last sound of the ます-form is し, て is added
examples: 3) かえります → かえって
8) いそぎます → いそいで

explanations: て is added to the ます-form
て is added to the ます-form
This expression is used to tell, request or invite the listener to do something
[Note] This is not a very polite way of asking someone to do something, so すみませんが is often added at the front
examples: 1) すみませんが，この 漢字[かんじ]の 読[よ]み方[かた]を 教[おし]えて ください。
1) Excuse me, could you teach me how to reach this kanji, please?
2) ボールペンで 名前[なまえ]は 書いて ください。
2) Please write your name with a ballpoint pen
3) どうぞ たくさん 食[た]べて ください。
3) Please eat as much as you want

explanations: This expression indicates that a certain action/motion is in progress
examples: 1) ミラーさんは 今[いま] 電話[でんわ]を かけて います。
1) Mr Miller is making a phone call now.
2) 今[いま] 雨[あめ]が 降[ふ]って いますか。
2) ... はい，降[ふ]って います。
2) ... いいえ，降[ふ]って いません。

topic: Verb ます-form ましょうか
explanations: This expression is used when the speaker is offering to do something for the listener
examples: 1) あしたも 来[き]ましょうか。
1) ... ええ，10時[じ]に 来[き]て ください。
2) 傘[かさ]を 貸[か]しましょうか。
2) Shall I lend you my umbrella?
2) ... すみません。お願[ねが]いします。
3) 荷物[にもつ]を 持[も]ちましょうか。

explanations: The particle が is used when describing an event that was felt through the five senses
It is also used when telling someone objectively about an event
examples: 1) 雨[あめ]が 降[ふ]って います。
2) ミラーさんが いませんね。
2) Mr Miller isnt here, is he?

explanations: The が in the すみませんが and 失礼[しつれい]ですが are not used in an antithetical sensse but as a casual preamble to a remark
examples: 1) すみませんが，塩[しお]を 取[と]って ください。
1) Excuse me, could you pass me the salt please?
2) 失礼[しつれい]ですが，お名前[なまえ]は？
2) Excuse me, but what is your name?
